Gradient Leakage Defense with Key-Lock Module for Federated Learning

Hanchi Ren , Jingjing Deng* , Xianghua Xie* ,
Xiaoke Ma, and Jianfeng Ma Hanchi Ren and Xianghua Xie are with the Department of Computer Science, Swansea University, United Kingdom. Jingjing Deng is with the Department of Computer Science, Durham University, United Kingdom. Xiaoke Ma is with the School of Computer Science and Technology, and Jianfeng Ma is with School of Cyber Engineering, Xidian University, China. The corresponding authors are Jingjing Deng and Xianghua Xie.
E-mail:{hanchi.ren, x.xie}@swansea.ac.uk, jingjing.deng@durham.ac.uk, and {xkma, jfma}@mail.xidian.edu.cn
Abstract

Federated Learning (FL) is a widely adopted privacy-preserving machine learning approach where private data remains local, enabling secure computations and the exchange of local model gradients between local clients and third-party parameter servers. However, recent findings reveal that privacy may be compromised and sensitive information potentially recovered from shared gradients. In this study, we offer detailed analysis and a novel perspective on understanding the gradient leakage problem. These theoretical works lead to a new gradient leakage defense technique that secures arbitrary model architectures using a private key-lock module. Only the locked gradient is transmitted to the parameter server for global model aggregation. Our proposed learning method is resistant to gradient leakage attacks, and the key-lock module is designed and trained to ensure that, without the private information of the key-lock module: a) reconstructing private training data from the shared gradient is infeasible; and b) the global model’s inference performance is significantly compromised. We discuss the theoretical underpinnings of why gradients can leak private information and provide theoretical proof of our method’s effectiveness. We conducted extensive empirical evaluations with a total of forty-four models on several popular benchmarks, demonstrating the robustness of our proposed approach in both maintaining model performance and defending against gradient leakage attacks.

Index Terms:
Federated Learning, Data Privacy, Gradient Leakage Defense, Distributed Learning, Deep Neural Network

1 Introduction

Deep Neural Networks (DNNs) are data-intensive, and growing public concerns about data privacy and personal information have garnered significant attention from researchers in recent years. Federated Learning (FL), a decentralized framework for collaborative privacy-preserving model training, was proposed to address the data privacy issue [1, 2, 3, 4]. This framework involves multiple training clients and a central server responsible for aggregating locally computed model gradients into a global model for all clients to share. Sensitive data remains exclusively accessible to its respective owner. Nonetheless, recent studies have shown that gradient-sharing schemes do not adequately protect sensitive and private data.

Zhu et al. [5] proposed the DLG method for recovering original training data by iteratively updating a randomly initialized input image and its associated label to approximate the true gradient. The updated input image is expected to converge towards the true image when the training is complete. However, DLG has been criticized for its instability and sensitivity to batch size and image resolution. Zhao et al. [6] demonstrated that the ground-truth label can be computed analytically from the gradient of the loss with respect to the Softmax layer and proposed Improved (iDLG). Geiping et al. [7] proposed an improvement to DLG called Inverting Gradient (IG) that uses magnitude-invariant cosine similarity as a loss function, making it more stable. IG can recover images up to 224∗224224224224*224 resolution and a batch size of 100 with acceptable success rates. In our previous work [8], we introduced a new method for recovering training data using a Generative Regression Neural Network (GRNN). GRNN consists of two generative model branches, one based on a Generative Adversarial Network (GAN) for generating fake training data and the other using a fully-connected architecture for generating corresponding labels. The training data is recovered by regressing the true and fake gradients, computed from the generated data pairs. Recently, Li et al. [9] proposed the Generative Gradient Leakage (GGL) method, which generates similar fake data using a pre-trained GAN. GGL is based on the idea of iDLG, inferring the true label and then updating the input sequence of GAN by matching the gradient. However, GGL only generates similar data given a label, and it does not aim to recover the original training data.

Recently, a number of strategies have been proposed in order to mitigate or overcome such leakage attacks, including gradient perturbation [5, 10, 11, 12, 8], data obfuscation or sanitization [13, 14, 15, 16, 17, 18], and hybrid methods [19, 20, 21, 22, 23]. Nonetheless, in the majority cases, a balance must be struck between privacy preservation and performance optimization. Specifically, for conventional encryption-based methodologies, the elevated computational complexity intrinsic to cryptographic operations demands substantial computational resources. An in-depth examination of gradient leakage ablation experiments was conducted by Wei et al. [24], in which the study quantitatively delineated the relationships between Deep Neural Network (DNN) architectural design and FL settings, encompassing factors such as batch size, image resolution, activation function, and the quantity of local iterations preceding gradient exchange. These findings are either directly or indirectly corroborated by several other studies. For instance, DLG proposes that the activation function must be twice-differentiable. The research also assesses the impact of leakage performance by altering the number of local training iterations on the client side. In [25], the authors introduced a neural network ownership verification technique, DeepIP, a concept referred to as a “digital passport”, which serves as input for the “passport function” responsible for generating the scale and shift parameters in the normalization layer. A key finding of this study is that the model’s inference performance will experience significant degradation in the presence of forged passports. In our proposed work, we show that transitioning the scale and shift parameters from trainable parameters to generated parameters has the potential to disrupt the information inheritance process during backward propagation.

In this study, we first establish, from a theoretical standpoint, that the feature maps computed from the fully-connected layer, convolutional layer, and Batch Normalization (BN) layer encompass the private information of input data. This information also coexists in the gradient during the backward propagation. Moreover, we propose that gradient leakage attacks are only viable when the gradient spaces between the global model and local models are adequately aligned. Consequently, we introduce FedKL, a key-lock module adept at differentiating, misaligning, and securing the gradient spaces with a private key while maintaining federated aggregation analogous to the standard FL framework. In essence, we reconfigure the scale and shift procedures in the normalization layer. A private key, i.e., a randomly generated sequence, is input into two fully-connected layers, and the resultant outputs serve as the proprietary coefficients for the scale and shift processes. Both theoretical analyses and experimental outcomes demonstrate that the proposed key-lock module is effective and efficient in defending against gradient leakage attacks, as the consistency of private information in the gradient is obscured. Consequently, a malicious attacker is unable to formulate forward-backward propagation without the private key and the gradient of the lock layer. Thus, it becomes infeasible to reconstruct local training data by approximating the shared gradient in the FL system. Our theoretical and experimental findings indicate that FedKL offers the following advantages:

  • •

    robust protection against gradient leakage attacks;

  • •

    negligible decline in inference performance compared to the model without the key-lock module;

  • •

    minimal additional computational cost associated with the key-lock module;

  • •

    significant reduction in inference performance when the private key of the key-lock module is absent;

  • •

    ability to adapt to arbitrary network architecture.

The remainder of this paper is structured as follows: Section 2 encompasses a discussion of relevant literature on gradient leakage attacks and associated defensive strategies; Section 3 introduces the proposed gradient leakage defense approach and private key-lock module, succeeded by an experimental evaluation and comparative analysis in Section 4; Finally, Section 5 offers concluding remarks and explores potential avenues for future research.

2 Related Work

Gradient leakage attacks seek to disclose private training data based on leaked gradients and represent a significant privacy-preserving threat to both centralized and collaborative Deep Learning (DL) systems. In centralized DL systems, membership inference is a common method for exposing private training data [26, 27, 28, 29, 30]. DLG [5] was one of the first studies to investigate private training data reconstruction from leaked gradients in a collaborative DL system. Following DLG, Geiping et al. [7] explored an alternative approach to unveiling private training data using an optimization-based method. They enhanced the stability of DLG by introducing a magnitude-invariant cosine similarity measurement for the loss function and demonstrated that prior knowledge facilitates a more efficient gradient leakage attack. Similarly, Jeon et al. [31] posited that gradient information alone is insufficient for revealing private training data. As a result, they proposed GIAS, which employs a pre-trained data-revealing model. Yin et al. [32] reported that in an image classification task, the ground-truth label could be easily discerned from the gradient in the last fully-connected layer, and BN statistics can significantly augment the gradient leakage attack, ultimately revealing high-resolution private training images.

Generative model-based methods can also facilitate gradient leakage attacks. Hitaj et al. [33] proposed a GAN-based data recovery method capable of generating a dataset with a distribution closely resembling that of the training dataset. Wang et al. [34] trained a GAN with a multitask discriminator for auxiliary identification, referred to as mGAN-AI, to generate private information based on the gradient. In our previous work [8], the GRNN was developed to reconstruct private training data and its corresponding label, handling large batch sizes and high-resolution images. In the GGL [9] study, a GAN was employed to create fake data. The weights of the GAN were pre-trained and fixed, with the trainable parameters in GGL being the input sequence of the GAN. The label inference component was derived from iDLG, requiring a batch size of 1. In contrast to other approaches, GGL utilized Covariance Matrix Adaptation Evolution Strategy (CMA-ES) as the optimizer to reduce variation in the generated data.

Many attempts have been dedicated to protecting private information leakage from gradients. A significant proportion of these, including gradient perturbation, data obfuscation or sanitization, Differential Privacy (DP), Homomorphic Encryption (HE), and Secure Multi-Party Computation (MPC) [21], attempt to safeguard private training data or publicly shared gradients transmitted between clients and servers. Zhu et al. [5] experimented with adding Gaussian and Laplacian noise, reporting that only the magnitude of distribution variance matters, not the noise type. Leakage attacks fail when the variance exceeds 10−2superscript10210^{-2}, but at this level of variance, the global model performance dramatically declines. Chamikara et al. [17] proposed a data perturbation method that preserves training data privacy without compromising model performance. The input dataset is treated as a data matrix and subjected to a multidimensional transformation in a new feature space. They perturbed the input data with various transformation scales to ensure adequate perturbation. However, the method relies on a centralized server controlling the generation of global perturbation parameters, and crucially, the perturbation method may corrupt the architectural information of image-based data. Wei et al. [23] employed DP to add noise to each client’s training dataset and introduced a per-example-based DP approach for the client, called Fed-CDP. To improve inference performance and defend against gradient leakage, a dynamic decay noise injection method is proposed. However, experimental results reveal that although the method prevents training data reconstruction from the gradient, inference accuracy significantly deteriorates. Moreover, the computational cost is high since DP is performed on each training sample. Both Privacy Enhancing Module (PRECODE) [18] and our proposed FedKL attempt to prevent input information from passing through the model when computing the gradient. PRECODE inserts two fully-connected layers before the output layer, resulting in substantial computational costs. Consequently, only three shallow DNNs were used for their experiments.

3 Proposed Method

In this section, we first demonstrate that the gradient information of a DNN during the back-propagation stage is strongly correlated with the input data and its corresponding label in a supervised learning context. Subsequently, we theoretically illustrate that by shifting the latent space, the private data cannot be recovered from the gradient without aligning the latent spaces. Based on these two theoretical discoveries, the key-lock module is proposed to safeguard the local gradient from leakage attacks. Finally, we present the novel FL framework with the key-lock module, referred to as FedKL, which illustrates how the proposed method protects the collaborative learning system from gradient leakage attacks.

3.1 Theoretical Analysis on Gradient Leakage

Recently, several studies have demonstrated that the input data information embedded in the gradient enables leakage attacks. Geiping et al. [7] established that for any fully-connected layer in a neural network, the derivative of the loss value concerning the layer’s output contains input data information. By employing the Chain Rule, the input of the fully-connected layer can be computed independently from the gradients of other layers. In this section, using typical supervised learning tasks, e.g. classification and regression, we extend this theory to the convolutional layer and BN layer.

Definition 1.

Gradient: suppose in a vector or matrix space, a function f:ℝn→ℝm:f→superscriptℝnsuperscriptℝm\textbf{f}:\mathbb{R}^{n}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}^{m} that maps a vector of length nnn to a vector with length mmm: f(x)=y,x∈ℝn;y∈ℝmformulae-sequencef(x)yformulae-sequencexsuperscriptℝnysuperscriptℝm\textbf{f(x)}=y,\ x\in\mathbb{R}^{n};\ y\in\mathbb{R}^{m}. The gradient is the derivative of a function f with respect to input x, and can be presented by the Jacobian Matrix:

∂f∂x=(∂f1∂x1⋯∂f1∂xn⋮⋱⋮∂fm∂x1⋯∂fm∂xn)fxmatrixsubscript𝑓1subscript𝑥1⋯subscript𝑓1subscript𝑥𝑛⋮⋱⋮subscript𝑓𝑚subscript𝑥1⋯subscript𝑓𝑚subscript𝑥𝑛\displaystyle\frac{\partial\textbf{f}}{\partial\textbf{x}}=\begin{pmatrix}\frac{\partial f_{1}}{\partial x_{1}}&\cdots&\frac{\partial f_{1}}{\partial x_{n}}\\ \vdots&\ddots&\vdots\\ \frac{\partial f_{m}}{\partial x_{1}}&\cdots&\frac{\partial f_{m}}{\partial x_{n}}\end{pmatrix} (1)
Definition 2.

Chain Rule: considering the derivative of a function of a function, i.e., g(f(x)). Assuming that the function is continuous and differentiable, the outer function is differentiable with respect to the inner function as an independent variable. Subsequently, the inner function is differentiable with respect to its independent variable xxx. According to the Chain Rule, the derivative of g with respect to x is:

∂g∂x=∂g∂f​∂f∂xgxgffx\displaystyle\frac{\partial\textbf{g}}{\partial\textbf{x}}=\frac{\partial\textbf{g}}{\partial\textbf{f}}\frac{\partial\textbf{f}}{\partial\textbf{x}} (2)
Claim 1.

The gradient of a linear neural network is strongly correlated with the input data and the corresponding ground-truth label.

Proof.

Assuming a simple linear regression example, the model is f​(x):y^=θ​x:𝑓𝑥^𝑦𝜃𝑥f(x):\hat{y}=\theta x, the loss function is Mean Square Error (MSE): ℒ​(x,y)=1N​∑(y^−y)2=1N​∑(θ​x−y)2ℒ𝑥𝑦1𝑁superscript^𝑦𝑦21𝑁superscript𝜃𝑥𝑦2\mathcal{L}(x,y)=\frac{1}{N}\sum(\hat{y}-y)^{2}=\frac{1}{N}\sum(\theta x-y)^{2}, where N𝑁N is the number of sample, y𝑦y is the ground-truth. The derivative of loss function ℒℒ\mathcal{L} with respect to the weight θ𝜃\theta on a batch of N𝑁N samples is:

∂ℒ∂θℒ𝜃\displaystyle\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial\theta} =∂∂θ​1N​∑i(xi⋅θ−yi)2absent𝜃1𝑁subscript𝑖superscript⋅subscript𝑥𝑖𝜃subscript𝑦𝑖2\displaystyle=\frac{\partial}{\partial\theta}\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i}(x_{i}\cdot\theta-y_{i})^{2} (3)
=1N​∑i∂∂θ​(xi⋅θ−yi)2absent1𝑁subscript𝑖𝜃superscript⋅subscript𝑥𝑖𝜃subscript𝑦𝑖2\displaystyle=\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i}\frac{\partial}{\partial\theta}(x_{i}\cdot\theta-y_{i})^{2}
=1N​∑i2⋅(xi⋅θ−yi)⋅∂(xi⋅θ−yi)∂θabsent1𝑁subscript𝑖⋅2⋅subscript𝑥𝑖𝜃subscript𝑦𝑖⋅subscript𝑥𝑖𝜃subscript𝑦𝑖𝜃\displaystyle=\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i}2\cdot(x_{i}\cdot\theta-y_{i})\cdot\frac{\partial(x_{i}\cdot\theta-y_{i})}{\partial\theta}
=1N​∑i2⋅xi⋅(y^−yi)absent1𝑁subscript𝑖⋅2subscript𝑥𝑖^𝑦subscript𝑦𝑖\displaystyle=\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i}2\cdot x_{i}\cdot(\hat{y}-y_{i})

In this case, the gradient of the model is positively related to the input to the function (i.e., x𝑥x) and the difference between the predicted label (y^^𝑦\hat{y}) and the ground-truth label (y𝑦y). This relationship implies that the gradient carries information about both the input data and the labels, which can be exploited in a gradient leakage attack. ∎

Claim 2.

In the context of a non-linear neural network, the gradient demonstrates a strong association with both the input data and the ground-truth label.

This substantiates that the gradient of the output layer encompasses information about the ground-truth label, which aligns with the findings in papers [6, 32]. In Eqn. 8, y^^𝑦\hat{y} represents the predicted probability distribution and y𝑦y denotes the one-hot distribution of the ground-truth label. Consequently, only the correct label yields a negative result for (y^−y)Tsuperscript^𝑦𝑦𝑇(\hat{y}-y)^{T}. Furthermore, a𝑎a, feature map as the output of the activation layer, passes the information of input data to the gradient of the output layer. The weight λ=λ′−η​(y^−y)T​a𝜆superscript𝜆′𝜂superscript^𝑦𝑦𝑇𝑎\lambda=\lambda^{\prime}-\eta(\hat{y}-y)^{T}a, where λ′superscript𝜆′\lambda^{\prime} represents the weight from the previous iteration and η𝜂\eta denotes the learning rate. In the ReLU layer, specific information is suppressed (set to 0), as seen in Eqn. 13. Notably, the non-zero gradients comprise three components: 1) the difference between the predicted probability distribution and the one-hot ground-truth label; 2) the weights of the subsequent fully-connected layer λ𝜆\lambda; and 3) the input of the current layer, which includes input data and feature maps. Given the gradient of each layer, every element in Eqns.13 and 16 is known; thus, the input data x𝑥x can be reconstructed. It can be concluded that the gradient in a non-linear neural network exhibits a strong correlation with the input data and ground-truth label. In accordance with the Chain Rule, the input information is also transmitted throughout the entire network. ∎

Claim 3.

The gradient in a Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) exhibits a strong correlation with both the input data and the ground-truth label. In the convolutional layers, input information and features are propagated through the network, influencing the gradients at each layer.

Proof.

In the context of a classification CNN composed of a convolutional layer, a ReLU activation layer, a fully-connected layer, a Softmax layer, and a CE loss function, the forward propagation process of the model can be described as follows:

x𝑥\displaystyle x =i​n​p​u​tabsent𝑖𝑛𝑝𝑢𝑡\displaystyle=input
u𝑢\displaystyle u =θ⊗x+b1absenttensor-product𝜃𝑥subscript𝑏1\displaystyle=\theta\otimes x+b_{1}
a𝑎\displaystyle a =R​e​L​U​(u)absent𝑅𝑒𝐿𝑈𝑢\displaystyle=ReLU(u)
a′superscript𝑎′\displaystyle a^{\prime} =f​l​a​t​t​e​n​(a)absent𝑓𝑙𝑎𝑡𝑡𝑒𝑛𝑎\displaystyle=flatten(a)
z𝑧\displaystyle z =λ⋅a′+b2absent⋅𝜆superscript𝑎′subscript𝑏2\displaystyle=\lambda\cdot a^{\prime}+b_{2}
y^^𝑦\displaystyle\hat{y} =s​o​f​t​m​a​x​(z)absent𝑠𝑜𝑓𝑡𝑚𝑎𝑥𝑧\displaystyle=softmax(z)
ℒℒ\displaystyle\mathcal{L} =C​E​(y,y^)absent𝐶𝐸𝑦^𝑦\displaystyle=CE(y,\hat{y})

The derivatives of ℒℒ\mathcal{L} with respect to λ𝜆\lambda and b2subscript𝑏2b_{2} are consistent with those Claim 2. Therefore, our primary focus will be on the gradient of the convolutional layer:

∂ℒ∂θℒ𝜃\displaystyle\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial\theta} =∂ℒ∂u​∂u∂θabsentℒ𝑢𝑢𝜃\displaystyle=\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial u}\frac{\partial u}{\partial\theta} (19)

∂ℒ∂uℒ𝑢\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial u} is known in Eqns. 13 & 16. According to the convolutional function, we have:

u(i,j,d)=∑h∑w∑cθ(d,h,w,c)⋅x(i+h,j+w,c)+b1​dsubscript𝑢𝑖𝑗𝑑subscriptℎsubscript𝑤subscript𝑐⋅subscript𝜃𝑑ℎ𝑤𝑐subscript𝑥𝑖ℎ𝑗𝑤𝑐subscript𝑏1𝑑\displaystyle u_{(i,j,d)}=\sum_{h}\sum_{w}\sum_{c}\theta_{(d,h,w,c)}\cdot x_{(i+h,j+w,c)}+b_{1d} (20)

where i𝑖i and j𝑗j represent the coordinates of the output feature map, d𝑑d denotes the index of the convolutional kernel, hℎh and w𝑤w are the coordinates of the kernel and c𝑐c is the index of the input channel. Then, the derivative of one pixel of the output feature map against any one specific parameter is:

∂u(i,j,d)∂θ(d,h′,w′,c′)subscript𝑢𝑖𝑗𝑑subscript𝜃𝑑superscriptℎ′superscript𝑤′superscript𝑐′\displaystyle\frac{\partial u_{(i,j,d)}}{\partial\theta_{(d,h^{\prime},w^{\prime},c^{\prime})}} =∂(∑h∑w∑cθ(d,h,w,c)⋅x(i+h,j+w,c)+b1​d)∂θ(d,h′,w′,c′)absentsubscriptℎsubscript𝑤subscript𝑐⋅subscript𝜃𝑑ℎ𝑤𝑐subscript𝑥𝑖ℎ𝑗𝑤𝑐subscript𝑏1𝑑subscript𝜃𝑑superscriptℎ′superscript𝑤′superscript𝑐′\displaystyle=\frac{\partial(\sum_{h}\sum_{w}\sum_{c}\theta_{(d,h,w,c)}\cdot x_{(i+h,j+w,c)}+b_{1d})}{\partial\theta_{(d,h^{\prime},w^{\prime},c^{\prime})}} (21)
=∂θ(d,h′,w′,c′)⋅x(i+h′,j+w′,c′)∂θ(d,h′,w′,c′)=x(i+h′,j+w′,c′)absent⋅subscript𝜃𝑑superscriptℎ′superscript𝑤′superscript𝑐′subscript𝑥𝑖superscriptℎ′𝑗superscript𝑤′superscript𝑐′subscript𝜃𝑑superscriptℎ′superscript𝑤′superscript𝑐′subscript𝑥𝑖superscriptℎ′𝑗superscript𝑤′superscript𝑐′\displaystyle=\frac{\partial\theta_{(d,h^{\prime},w^{\prime},c^{\prime})}\cdot x_{(i+h^{\prime},j+w^{\prime},c^{\prime})}}{\partial\theta_{(d,h^{\prime},w^{\prime},c^{\prime})}}=x_{(i+h^{\prime},j+w^{\prime},c^{\prime})}

All parameters contribute to the computation of the final model output, enabling the transformation of Eqn.19 into the derivative of the loss function with respect to any convolutional layer parameter (see Eqn.22). It is worth noting that each convolutional kernel is associated with only one output channel, meaning that the first kernel with the input generates the first channel of the output, the second kernel with the input results in the second channel of the output, and so on.

∂ℒ∂θ(d,h′,w′,c′)ℒsubscript𝜃𝑑superscriptℎ′superscript𝑤′superscript𝑐′\displaystyle\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial\theta_{(d,h^{\prime},w^{\prime},c^{\prime})}} =∂ℒ∂u(i,j,d)​∂u(i,j,d)∂θ(d,h′,w′,c′)absentℒsubscript𝑢𝑖𝑗𝑑subscript𝑢𝑖𝑗𝑑subscript𝜃𝑑superscriptℎ′superscript𝑤′superscript𝑐′\displaystyle=\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial u_{(i,j,d)}}\frac{\partial u_{(i,j,d)}}{\partial\theta_{(d,h^{\prime},w^{\prime},c^{\prime})}} (22)
=∂ℒ∂u(i,j,d)⋅x(i+h′,j+w′,c′)absent⋅ℒsubscript𝑢𝑖𝑗𝑑subscript𝑥𝑖superscriptℎ′𝑗superscript𝑤′superscript𝑐′\displaystyle=\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial u_{(i,j,d)}}\cdot x_{(i+h^{\prime},j+w^{\prime},c^{\prime})}

Regarding the derivative of the loss function with respect to the bias b1​dsubscript𝑏1𝑑b_{1d}, we have:

∂u(i,j,d)∂b1​dsubscript𝑢𝑖𝑗𝑑subscript𝑏1𝑑\displaystyle\frac{\partial u_{(i,j,d)}}{\partial b_{1d}} =1absent1\displaystyle=1 (23)
∂ℒ∂b1​dℒsubscript𝑏1𝑑\displaystyle\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial b_{1d}} =∑i∑j∂ℒ∂u(i,j,d)absentsubscript𝑖subscript𝑗ℒsubscript𝑢𝑖𝑗𝑑\displaystyle=\sum_{i}\sum_{j}\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial u_{(i,j,d)}} (24)

In conclusion, similar to Claim 1 and Claim 2, referring to Eqns. 8, 9, 13 & 16, the gradient in the CNN is also highly correlated to the input data and ground-truth label. Our previous work[8] has demonstrated that higher label inference accuracy leads to better reconstruction performance of the input data. This idea has also been presented in papers [6, 32], but the fundamental rationale for such phenomena was not explored. ∎

It has been demonstrated that the gradients in both the convolutional and fully-connected layers of a neural network contain ample information about the input data and the associated ground-truth labels to enable their reconstruction. The purpose of the following analysis is to establish that the gradient in the BN layer also encodes information about the input data and the ground-truth label.

Definition 3.

BN Layer: To address the vanishing gradient problem arising from input values reaching the saturation zone of the non-linear function, the BN layer is utilized for each hidden neuron in a DNN. This layer normalizes the input values to a standard normal distribution, which shifts the input values to a region that is more responsive to the input and helps mitigate the vanishing gradient problem.

Suppose there is a mini-batch of input data: ℬ={u1​…​uN}ℬsubscript𝑢1…subscript𝑢𝑁\mathcal{B}=\{u_{1}...u_{N}\}, where N𝑁N is the batch size. The BN function can be defined as:

μℬsubscript𝜇ℬ\displaystyle\mu_{\mathcal{B}} =1N​∑nunabsent1𝑁subscript𝑛subscript𝑢𝑛\displaystyle=\frac{1}{N}\sum_{n}u_{n} (25)
σℬ2subscriptsuperscript𝜎2ℬ\displaystyle\sigma^{2}_{\mathcal{B}} =1N​∑n(un−μℬ)2absent1𝑁subscript𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑢𝑛subscript𝜇ℬ2\displaystyle=\frac{1}{N}\sum_{n}(u_{n}-\mu_{\mathcal{B}})^{2} (26)
u^^𝑢\displaystyle\hat{u} =u−μℬσℬ2+ϵabsent𝑢subscript𝜇ℬsubscriptsuperscript𝜎2ℬitalic-ϵ\displaystyle=\frac{u-\mu_{\mathcal{B}}}{\sqrt{\sigma^{2}_{\mathcal{B}}+\epsilon}} (27)
s𝑠\displaystyle s =γ⋅u^+βabsent⋅𝛾^𝑢𝛽\displaystyle=\gamma\cdot\hat{u}+\beta (28)
Claim 4.

The gradient in the BN layer contains information about the input data and ground-truth labels.

Proof.

We modify the network in Claim 3 by adding a BN layer after the convolutional layer:

x𝑥\displaystyle x =i​n​p​u​tabsent𝑖𝑛𝑝𝑢𝑡\displaystyle=input
u𝑢\displaystyle u =θ⊗x+b1absenttensor-product𝜃𝑥subscript𝑏1\displaystyle=\theta\otimes x+b_{1}
s𝑠\displaystyle s =B​Nγ,β​(u)absent𝐵subscript𝑁𝛾𝛽𝑢\displaystyle=BN_{\gamma,\beta}(u)
a𝑎\displaystyle a =R​e​L​U​(s)absent𝑅𝑒𝐿𝑈𝑠\displaystyle=ReLU(s)
a′superscript𝑎′\displaystyle a^{\prime} =f​l​a​t​t​e​n​(a)absent𝑓𝑙𝑎𝑡𝑡𝑒𝑛𝑎\displaystyle=flatten(a)
z𝑧\displaystyle z =λ⋅a′+b2absent⋅𝜆superscript𝑎′subscript𝑏2\displaystyle=\lambda\cdot a^{\prime}+b_{2}
y^^𝑦\displaystyle\hat{y} =s​o​f​t​m​a​x​(z)absent𝑠𝑜𝑓𝑡𝑚𝑎𝑥𝑧\displaystyle=softmax(z)
ℒℒ\displaystyle\mathcal{L} =C​E​(y,y^)absent𝐶𝐸𝑦^𝑦\displaystyle=CE(y,\hat{y})

where γ𝛾\gamma and β𝛽\beta are parameters in BN layer. The derivative of the loss function with respect to γ𝛾\gamma and β𝛽\beta are:

∂ℒ∂γℒ𝛾\displaystyle\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial\gamma} =∂ℒ∂s​∂s∂γ=(y^−y)⋅λ∘s​g​n​(a)⋅u^absentℒ𝑠𝑠𝛾⋅⋅^𝑦𝑦𝜆𝑠𝑔𝑛𝑎^𝑢\displaystyle=\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial s}\frac{\partial s}{\partial\gamma}=(\hat{y}-y)\cdot\lambda\circ sgn(a)\cdot\hat{u} (29)
∂ℒ∂βℒ𝛽\displaystyle\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial\beta} =∂ℒ∂s​∂s∂β=(y^−y)⋅λ∘s​g​n​(a)absentℒ𝑠𝑠𝛽⋅^𝑦𝑦𝜆𝑠𝑔𝑛𝑎\displaystyle=\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial s}\frac{\partial s}{\partial\beta}=(\hat{y}-y)\cdot\lambda\circ sgn(a) (30)

Same as Claims 1, 2 and 3, we can show that the gradient of BN layer is correlated to the input data and ground-truth label. However, to compute the gradient of the network accurately using the Chain Rule, it is necessary to calculate the derivative of the loss function with respect to the input of the BN layer, ∂ℒ∂uℒ𝑢\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial u}. This computation is not trivial, as we know that the normalized output u^^𝑢\hat{u}, variance value σℬ2subscriptsuperscript𝜎2ℬ\sigma^{2}_{\mathcal{B}} and mean value μℬsubscript𝜇ℬ\mu_{\mathcal{B}} are all related to the input u𝑢u. So we first compute the derivative of ∂ℒ∂u^ℒ^𝑢\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial\hat{u}}, ∂ℒ∂σℬ2ℒsubscriptsuperscript𝜎2ℬ\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial\sigma^{2}_{\mathcal{B}}} and ∂ℒ∂μℬℒsubscript𝜇ℬ\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial\mu_{\mathcal{B}}}:

∂ℒ∂u^ℒ^𝑢\displaystyle\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial\hat{u}} =∂ℒ∂s​∂s∂u^=(y^−y)⋅λ∘s​g​n​(a)⋅γabsentℒ𝑠𝑠^𝑢⋅⋅^𝑦𝑦𝜆𝑠𝑔𝑛𝑎𝛾\displaystyle=\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial s}\frac{\partial s}{\partial\hat{u}}=(\hat{y}-y)\cdot\lambda\circ sgn(a)\cdot\gamma (31)
∂ℒ∂σℬ2ℒsubscriptsuperscript𝜎2ℬ\displaystyle\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial\sigma^{2}_{\mathcal{B}}} =∂ℒ∂s​∂s∂u^​∂u^∂σℬ2absentℒ𝑠𝑠^𝑢^𝑢subscriptsuperscript𝜎2ℬ\displaystyle=\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial s}\frac{\partial s}{\partial\hat{u}}\frac{\partial\hat{u}}{\partial\sigma^{2}_{\mathcal{B}}} (32)
=−12​∂ℒ∂u^⋅(u−μℬ)⋅(σℬ2+ϵ)−32absent⋅12ℒ^𝑢𝑢subscript𝜇ℬsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝜎2ℬitalic-ϵ32\displaystyle=-\frac{1}{2}\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial\hat{u}}\cdot(u-\mu_{\mathcal{B}})\cdot(\sigma^{2}_{\mathcal{B}}+\epsilon)^{-\frac{3}{2}}
∂ℒ∂μℬℒsubscript𝜇ℬ\displaystyle\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial\mu_{\mathcal{B}}} =∂ℒ∂u^​∂u^∂μℬ+∂ℒ∂σℬ2​∂σℬ2∂μℬabsentℒ^𝑢^𝑢subscript𝜇ℬℒsubscriptsuperscript𝜎2ℬsubscriptsuperscript𝜎2ℬsubscript𝜇ℬ\displaystyle=\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial\hat{u}}\frac{\partial\hat{u}}{\partial\mu_{\mathcal{B}}}+\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial\sigma^{2}_{\mathcal{B}}}\frac{\partial\sigma^{2}_{\mathcal{B}}}{\partial\mu_{\mathcal{B}}} (33)
=∂ℒ∂u^⋅−1σℬ2+ϵ+∂ℒ∂σℬ2⋅−2​(u−μℬ)Nabsent⋅ℒ^𝑢1subscriptsuperscript𝜎2ℬitalic-ϵ⋅ℒsubscriptsuperscript𝜎2ℬ2𝑢subscript𝜇ℬ𝑁\displaystyle=\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial\hat{u}}\cdot\frac{-1}{\sqrt{\sigma^{2}_{\mathcal{B}}+\epsilon}}+\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial\sigma^{2}_{\mathcal{B}}}\cdot\frac{-2(u-\mu_{\mathcal{B}})}{N}

Then we have:

∂ℒ∂uℒ𝑢\displaystyle\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial u} =∂ℒ∂u^​∂u^∂u+∂ℒ∂σℬ2​∂σℬ2∂u+∂ℒ∂μℬ​∂μℬ∂uabsentℒ^𝑢^𝑢𝑢ℒsubscriptsuperscript𝜎2ℬsubscriptsuperscript𝜎2ℬ𝑢ℒsubscript𝜇ℬsubscript𝜇ℬ𝑢\displaystyle=\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial\hat{u}}\frac{\partial\hat{u}}{\partial u}+\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial\sigma^{2}_{\mathcal{B}}}\frac{\partial\sigma^{2}_{\mathcal{B}}}{\partial u}+\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial\mu_{\mathcal{B}}}\frac{\partial\mu_{\mathcal{B}}}{\partial u} (34)
=∂ℒ∂u^⋅1σℬ2+ϵ+∂ℒ∂σℬ2⋅2​(u−μℬ)N+∂ℒ∂μℬ⋅1Nabsent⋅ℒ^𝑢1subscriptsuperscript𝜎2ℬitalic-ϵ⋅ℒsubscriptsuperscript𝜎2ℬ2𝑢subscript𝜇ℬ𝑁⋅ℒsubscript𝜇ℬ1𝑁\displaystyle=\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial\hat{u}}\cdot\frac{1}{\sqrt{\sigma^{2}_{\mathcal{B}}+\epsilon}}+\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial\sigma^{2}_{\mathcal{B}}}\cdot\frac{2(u-\mu_{\mathcal{B}})}{N}+\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial\mu_{\mathcal{B}}}\cdot\frac{1}{N}

In a typical FL setting, a malicious server has access to the gradients of each layer, allowing for the calculation of all variables in the equations presented above. The gradients obtained from Eqns. 22 & 29 contain rich information about the input data in both shallow and deep layers. Additionally, Eqn. 29 reveals that the trainable parameter γ𝛾\gamma is highly related to the input feature map u^^𝑢\hat{u}, as observed in Eqns. 32 & 33. Consequently, the derivative of the loss function with respect to the output of the convolutional layer u𝑢u, as shown in Eqn. 34, contains sufficiently rich input data information to enable deep leakage attacks. ∎

Referring to all the reasoning processes above, we can conclude that for any arbitrary CNN:

Proposition 1.

The gradients of the fully-connected layer, convolutional layer, and BN layer in an image classification task contain sufficient information about the input data and ground-truth label, making it possible for an attacker to reconstruct them by regressing the gradients.

3.2 Theoretical Analysis on Proposed Leakage Defense

Proposition 2.

For a CNN, embedding a key-lock module into the model can prevent the inheritance of the private input information through the gradient, where this is achieved by dropping the information of the input data in the gradient.

Proof.

Theoretical analysis is conducted to investigate how the key-lock module prevents the inheritance of private information throughout the gradient in a CNN. Unlike in the traditional BN layer where λ𝜆\lambda and β𝛽\beta are trainable parameters, the key-lock module generates them as the output of two fully-connected layers called lock, which take a private input sequence called key as input. The proposed approach introduces new trainable parameters, namely ω𝜔\omega, ϕitalic-ϕ\phi, and two biases b2subscript𝑏2b_{2} and b3subscript𝑏3b_{3}. The network is defined as follows:

x𝑥\displaystyle x =i​n​p​u​tabsent𝑖𝑛𝑝𝑢𝑡\displaystyle=input
k𝑘\displaystyle k =k​e​yabsent𝑘𝑒𝑦\displaystyle=key
u𝑢\displaystyle u =θ⊗x+b1absenttensor-product𝜃𝑥subscript𝑏1\displaystyle=\theta\otimes x+b_{1}
γ𝛾\displaystyle\gamma =ω⋅k+b2absent⋅𝜔𝑘subscript𝑏2\displaystyle=\omega\cdot k+b_{2}
β𝛽\displaystyle\beta =ϕ⋅k+b3absent⋅italic-ϕ𝑘subscript𝑏3\displaystyle=\phi\cdot k+b_{3}
s𝑠\displaystyle s =B​Nγ,β​(u)absent𝐵subscript𝑁𝛾𝛽𝑢\displaystyle=BN_{\gamma,\beta}(u)
a𝑎\displaystyle a =R​e​L​U​(s)absent𝑅𝑒𝐿𝑈𝑠\displaystyle=ReLU(s)
a′superscript𝑎′\displaystyle a^{\prime} =f​l​a​t​t​e​n​(a)absent𝑓𝑙𝑎𝑡𝑡𝑒𝑛𝑎\displaystyle=flatten(a)
z𝑧\displaystyle z =λ⋅a′+b4absent⋅𝜆superscript𝑎′subscript𝑏4\displaystyle=\lambda\cdot a^{\prime}+b_{4}
y^^𝑦\displaystyle\hat{y} =s​o​f​t​m​a​x​(z)absent𝑠𝑜𝑓𝑡𝑚𝑎𝑥𝑧\displaystyle=softmax(z)
ℒℒ\displaystyle\mathcal{L} =C​E​(y,y^)absent𝐶𝐸𝑦^𝑦\displaystyle=CE(y,\hat{y})

The derivative of the loss function with respect to ω𝜔\omega and ϕitalic-ϕ\phi are:

∂ℒ∂ωℒ𝜔\displaystyle\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial\omega} =∂ℒ∂s​∂s∂ω=(y^−y)⋅λ∘s​g​n​(a)⋅k⋅u^absentℒ𝑠𝑠𝜔⋅⋅^𝑦𝑦𝜆𝑠𝑔𝑛𝑎𝑘^𝑢\displaystyle=\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial s}\frac{\partial s}{\partial\omega}=(\hat{y}-y)\cdot\lambda\circ sgn(a)\cdot k\cdot\hat{u} (35)
∂ℒ∂ϕℒitalic-ϕ\displaystyle\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial\phi} =∂ℒ∂s​∂s∂ϕ=(y^−y)⋅λ∘s​g​n​(a)⋅kabsentℒ𝑠𝑠italic-ϕ⋅⋅^𝑦𝑦𝜆𝑠𝑔𝑛𝑎𝑘\displaystyle=\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial s}\frac{\partial s}{\partial\phi}=(\hat{y}-y)\cdot\lambda\circ sgn(a)\cdot k (36)

The gradient in the lock layer is found to be closely related to the key sequence and feature map, which makes it possible for an attacker to infer the gradient of the lock layer given the key and leak the input data. To address this issue, we propose to keep both the key sequence and the weight of the lock layer private in our proposed method, FedKL. Once embedding the key-lock module, then Eqn. 31 can be rewritten:

∂ℒ∂u^ℒ^𝑢\displaystyle\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial\hat{u}} =∂ℒ∂s​∂s∂u^=∂ℒ∂s⋅(ω⋅k+b2)absentℒ𝑠𝑠^𝑢⋅ℒ𝑠⋅𝜔𝑘subscript𝑏2\displaystyle=\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial s}\frac{\partial s}{\partial\hat{u}}=\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial s}\cdot(\omega\cdot k+b_{2}) (37)
=(y^−y)⋅λ∘s​g​n​(a)⋅(ω⋅k+b2)absent⋅⋅^𝑦𝑦𝜆𝑠𝑔𝑛𝑎⋅𝜔𝑘subscript𝑏2\displaystyle=(\hat{y}-y)\cdot\lambda\circ sgn(a)\cdot(\omega\cdot k+b_{2})

The key sequence k𝑘k, lock layer’s weight ω𝜔\omega, and bias b2subscript𝑏2b_{2} are considered confidential in our proposed FedKL. In contrast to Section 3.1 Claim 4, the unknown γ𝛾\gamma and β𝛽\beta make it impossible to compute the components in Eqns. 32, 33 & 34. Similarly, in Eqn. 29, u^^𝑢\hat{u} can be computed, but s𝑠s cannot be determined in Eqn. 28. Therefore, it is not possible to infer the input information from the feature map s𝑠s. The proposed key-lock module effectively prevents the feature map from inheriting the input information and carrying it throughout the gradient when the private key and parameter of the lock module are unknown to the attacker. ∎

3.3 Key-Lock Module

A BN layer typically succeeds a convolutional layer and encompasses two processing stages: normalization followed by scaling and shifting. The coefficients for scale and shift comprise two trainable parameters that are updated via back-propagation. Stemming from the theoretical examination earlier, we propose a key-lock module to defend against gradient leakage attacks in FL, referred to as FedKL. This module can be incorporated subsequent to the convolution-normalization block, wherein the scale factor (γ∈ℝO𝛾superscriptℝ𝑂\gamma\in\mathbb{R}^{O}) and the shift bias (β∈ℝO𝛽superscriptℝ𝑂\beta\in\mathbb{R}^{O}) cease to be trainable parameters and instead become outputs of the key-lock module. Here, O𝑂O denotes the number of output channels of the convolutional layer. The input of the convolutional layer is represented as Xc​o​n​v∈ℝB×C×W×Hsubscript𝑋𝑐𝑜𝑛𝑣superscriptℝ𝐵𝐶𝑊𝐻X_{conv}\in\mathbb{R}^{B\times C\times W\times H}, with B𝐵B denoting the batch size, C𝐶C representing the number of channels, and W𝑊W and H𝐻H signifying the width and height of the input image, respectively. The weight in the convolutional layer is denoted as Wc​o​n​v∈ℝC×O×K×Ksubscript𝑊𝑐𝑜𝑛𝑣superscriptℝ𝐶𝑂𝐾𝐾W_{conv}\in\mathbb{R}^{C\times O\times K\times K}, with K𝐾K indicating the kernel size. We define the input key, Xk​e​y∈ℝSsubscript𝑋𝑘𝑒𝑦superscriptℝ𝑆X_{key}\in\mathbb{R}^{S}, as having a length of S𝑆S, and the weight of the key-lock module as Wl​o​c​k∈ℝS×Osubscript𝑊𝑙𝑜𝑐𝑘superscriptℝ𝑆𝑂W_{lock}\in\mathbb{R}^{S\times O}. The bias is represented as b𝑏b. Therefore, the embedding transformation ℱ​()ℱ\mathcal{F}() can be formulated as:

ℱ​(Xc​o​n​v,Xk​e​y)ℱsubscript𝑋𝑐𝑜𝑛𝑣subscript𝑋𝑘𝑒𝑦\displaystyle\mathcal{F}(X_{conv},X_{key}) =γ⋅(Xc​o​n​v⊗Wc​o​n​v)+βabsent⋅𝛾tensor-productsubscript𝑋𝑐𝑜𝑛𝑣subscript𝑊𝑐𝑜𝑛𝑣𝛽\displaystyle=\gamma\cdot(X_{conv}\otimes W_{conv})+\beta
γ𝛾\displaystyle\gamma =Xk​e​y⋅Wl​o​c​k−γ+bl​o​c​k−γabsent⋅subscript𝑋𝑘𝑒𝑦subscript𝑊𝑙𝑜𝑐𝑘𝛾subscript𝑏𝑙𝑜𝑐𝑘𝛾\displaystyle=X_{key}\cdot W_{lock-\gamma}+b_{lock-\gamma}
β𝛽\displaystyle\beta =Xk​e​y⋅Wl​o​c​k−β+bl​o​c​k−βabsent⋅subscript𝑋𝑘𝑒𝑦subscript𝑊𝑙𝑜𝑐𝑘𝛽subscript𝑏𝑙𝑜𝑐𝑘𝛽\displaystyle=X_{key}\cdot W_{lock-\beta}+b_{lock-\beta} (38)

where the convolution operation is denoted by ⊗tensor-product\otimes, while the inner product is represented by ⋅⋅\cdot. It is important to note that γ𝛾\gamma and β𝛽\beta in the general normalization layer are trainable parameters; however, in our proposed methodology, they are the outputs of the lock layer, given the private key sequence. Figure 2 demonstrates a typical DNN building block, incorporating both a general convolution-normalization module and the proposed key-lock module.

3.4 FL with Key-Lock Module

It is crucial to emphasize that the proposed key-lock module solely modifies the DNN architecture and does not require alterations to the FL strategy. In a conventional FL system, the global model is initially instantiated on the server and subsequently distributed to each client for secure local training. Local gradients from clients are aggregated on the server, converging into a new global model for the subsequent round of local training. To implement the proposed key-lock module within the system, the server first initializes the model with the key-lock module and then distributes the model to each client. Individual clients generate their own private key sequences for local training. At each periodic aggregation stage, the gradient of the model, excluding the lock layer, is merged at the server to generate the new global model. Throughout the process, both the key sequence and lock layer of each client are maintained as strictly confidential and securely localized. The global model does not retain any information from a client’s key-lock module; therefore, the global model and gradient from the local client cannot be employed for data reconstruction attacks. In the subsequent round of local training, each client first updates its own model using the distributed global model, without updating the lock layer. The client’s lock layer is then integrated into the new model. Figure 3 details a FL system incorporating the key-lock module.

4 Experiments

In this section, we first introduce the datasets and metrics employed for benchmark evaluation. Then, we present three sets of experiments to assess: 1) the influence of prediction accuracy of DNNs with the proposed key-lock module; 2) the effectiveness of defending against state-of-the-art gradient leakage attacks, including DLG, GRNN, and GGL; 3) the ablation study of various key hyperparameters of DNNs and training settings.

4.1 Benchmarks and Metrics

Our experiments utilize four popular public benchmarks: MNIST [37], CIFAR-10 [38], CIFAR-100 [38] and ILSVRC2012 [39]. Four evaluation metrics are employed to quantify the quality of the generated image, including MSE, Peak Signal-to-Noise Ratio (PSNR), Learned Perceptual Image Patch Similarity (LPIPS) [40] and Structure Similarity Index Measure (SSIM) [41]. To allow maximum capacity for gradient leakage attacks and hence to evaluate defense capability, the batch size is set to 1. Consequently, the reconstructed image and the true image can be directly matched. MSE measures the pixel-wise L2 difference between the reconstructed image and the true image. Formally, MSE is expressed as M​S​E​(X,X^)=‖X−X^‖2𝑀𝑆𝐸𝑋^𝑋subscriptnorm𝑋^𝑋2MSE(X,\hat{X})=||X-\hat{X}||_{2}, where X𝑋X denotes the true image and X^^𝑋\hat{X} represents the reconstructed image. PSNR is a criterion for image quality assessment, defined as the logarithm of the ratio of the squared maximum value of RGB image fluctuation over MSE between two images. The definition is given as: P​S​N​R​(X,X^)=10⋅lg⁡(2552M​S​E​(X,X^))𝑃𝑆𝑁𝑅𝑋^𝑋⋅10lgsuperscript2552𝑀𝑆𝐸𝑋^𝑋PSNR(X,\hat{X})=10\cdot\lg(\frac{255^{2}}{MSE(X,\hat{X})}). A higher PSNR score indicates greater similarity between the two images. LPIPS essentially computes the similarity between two image patches using predefined networks. We employ two neural networks, VGGNet [42] and AlexNet [43], to perceptually evaluate the similarity of two images. This approach is validated to be consistent with human perception. A lower LPIPS score signifies that the two images are perceptually more similar. SSIM assesses the proximity of image distortion by detecting changes in structural information. A higher SSIM score implies a better match. The proposed key-lock module is exclusively embedded in the first convolution-normalization block for all experiments in this study. The length of the randomly generated key sequence is 102410241024. The output dimension is 161616 for ResNet-20 and ResNet-32 on CIFAR-10 and CIFAR-100 datasets, and 646464 for ResNet-18 and ResNet-34 on ILSVRC2012. The framework used to implement the neural network models is PyTorch [44]. Our implementation of proposed FedKL is publicly available 111https://github.com/Rand2AI/FedKL.

4.2 Accuracy Impact

In order to assess the impact on performance, we devised two approaches: 1) centralized training with or without the key-lock module, and 2) collaborative training within the Federated Averaging (FedAvg) framework, also with or without the key-lock module. We employed LeNet[35], VGGNet[42], and ResNet[36] as the fundamental networks for training image classification models. A total of forty-four models were trained, utilizing eleven experimental configurations and two distinct training methodologies (centralized and federated), to compare standard networks and those incorporating key-lock modules. The findings are presented in Table I.

Overall, the most favorable results are observed when centralized training is implemented. For instance, LeNet on MNIST yields the highest performance of 99.05%percent99.0599.05\% accuracy according to paper [35], while ResNet-20 achieves the maximum accuracy of 91.63%percent91.6391.63\% on CIFAR-10 and 67.59%percent67.5967.59\% on CIFAR-100. The addition of the key-lock module does not lead to a significant decline in model inference performance. In certain instances, models incorporating the key-lock module even outperform those without it. For example, ResNet-20 on CIFAR-100 attains a testing accuracy of 61.97%percent61.9761.97\% within the FedKL framework, which is 5.79%percent5.795.79\% higher than the conventional FedAvg model that achieves 58.58%percent58.5858.58\%. The most substantial performance enhancement is observed with VGG-16 on CIFAR-100, where the FedKL model attains an accuracy of 73.06%percent73.0673.06\%, an improvement of 18.43%percent18.4318.43\% over the 61.69%percent61.6961.69\% achieved using FedAvg. Conversely, for experiments utilizing images with a resolution of 32∗32323232*32, optimal performance is obtained with centralized configurations without the key-lock module. Nevertheless, we note that the centralized setup incorporating the proposed key-lock module achieves the highest prediction accuracy when the resolution is increased to 224∗224224224224*224. Moreover, the outcomes from ResNet-18, ResNet-34, and VGG-16 indicate that models with the key-lock module significantly outperform those without it in both centralized and FL systems.

In Table II, we illustrate testing accuracies and losses in relation to training epochs for various networks using the CIFAR-10 and CIFAR-100 datasets. All models are trained in the centralized mode. The performance disparities between models with and without the key-lock module are relatively minor. In particular, the convergence trends exhibit a strong correlation in numerous instances, such as with ResNet-20 and ResNet-32 trained on CIFAR-100, and ResNet-18 trained on CIFAR-10. As mentioned previously, when higher resolution is employed, improved prediction performance can be observed utilizing the proposed key-lock module. It is logical to infer that this performance enhancement stems from the increased learning capacity derived from the additional two fully-connected layers present in the key-lock module.

To further understand the impact of the key-lock module on model performance, a comparison was conducted between local and global models by inputting a randomly generated key sequence and employing the initial weights of the lock layer on the server at each training round. Given that the proposed FedKL learns a personalized model due to the unique private key, the accuracies of FedKL, as presented in Table I, are averaged over all local clients. Each client’s accuracy is derived from their privately owned key sequence and trained key-lock layer’s parameters. The optimal model is selected from all training rounds, with the average accuracy representing the mean of all clients’ optimal performances. The “Random” row results are obtained by utilizing a randomly generated key sequence and random lock layer weights.

In Table III, the performance discrepancy is more pronounced for networks with fewer parameters compared to those with a higher number of parameters. The relationship between the lock layer’s parameter count and the model’s total parameter count was quantified, revealing a positive correlation between the performance gap and the weight proportion. As the lock layer parameter proportion decreases, the performance gap narrows. For instance, the smallest network, LeNet, exhibits the highest parameter proportion of 22.43%percent22.4322.43\% and the largest performance gap of 87.00%percent87.0087.00\% on the model with the best average performance of 97.45%percent97.4597.45\%. The parameter proportion of ResNet-20 exceeds that ofResNet-32, yet ResNet-20 outperforms ResNet-32 with a 33.46%percent33.4633.46\% accuracy gap compared to 19.03%percent19.0319.03\% on CIFAR-100. However, the performance gap of ResNet-20 is smaller than that of ResNet-32 (9.28%percent9.289.28\% vs. 13.38%percent13.3813.38\%) on CIFAR-10. The accuracy gaps of ResNet-18 are larger than those of ResNet-34 (2.25%percent2.252.25\% vs. 1.50%percent1.501.50\% on CIFAR-10 and 12.59%percent12.5912.59\% vs. 6.85%percent6.856.85\% on CIFAR-100). VGG-16, with the lowest parameter proportion of 0.097%percent0.0970.097\%, exhibits the smallest performance gaps of 0.32%percent0.320.32\% and 1.46%percent1.461.46\% on CIFAR-10 and CIFAR-100, respectively. Apart from network architecture, the dataset exerts a non-negligible influence, i.e., CIFAR-100, with a greater number of classes, consistently yields a larger accuracy gap than CIFAR-10, which has fewer classes. This phenomenon is observed in all experiments.

4.3 Defense Performance

To assess the defensive efficacy against gradient leakage attacks, three state-of-the-art attack methods were employed: DLG [5], GRNN [8], and GGL [9]. A batch size of 1 and resolution of 32∗32323232*32 were used for MNIST, CIFAR-10, and CIFAR-100. ILSVRC2012 utilized a resolution of 256∗256256256256*256 instead of 224∗224224224224*224, as GRNN is only capable of generating images with resolutions that are exponential multiples of 222. Images with lower resolution were upsampled using linear interpolation.

In Table IV, qualitative results are presented to demonstrate the comparative performance of defense efficacy against targeted leakage attacks, including DLG and GRNN, with various backbone networks and benchmark datasets. DLG consistently fails when employing ResNet-20 and ResNet-18, and as a result, no data is presented. In the case of utilizing LeNet, the reconstructed image is entirely perturbed once the key-lock module is integrated into the network. When a BN layer or key-lock module was incorporated into LeNet, DLG failed to reconstruct accurate images in all experiments, as DLG directly regresses image pixels by approximating the gradient. In other words, DLG can only reconstruct the true image from a gradient with explicit input data information (refer to Section 3.1 Claim 1: Eqn. 3, Claim 2: Eqn. 13, and Claim 3: Eqn. 22). However, both the BN layer and key-lock module re-normalize feature maps, leading to latent space misalignment and input data information ambiguity within the gradient (see Section 3.1 Claim 4: Eqn. 34 and Proposition 2 Eqn. 37). According to the quantitative results on gradient leakage attacks in Table VI, GRNN is more potent than DLG. Nevertheless, the proposed key-lock module can still effectively prevent true image leakage from gradient-based reconstruction. When employing GRNN on ResNet-18 with an image resolution of 256∗256256256256*256, the reconstructed image is not recognizable for private data identification, even though the reconstructed image contains minimal, albeit visible, information from the true image.

The GGL first generates an image using the inferred ground-truth label to specify the image category, then fine-tunes the generated image based on the gradient information to make it as similar as possible to the true image. In Table V, the model with the key-lock module generates samples with the same category as the true images. However, it can be observed that the appearances and spatial distributions are significantly different from the true image (see the w/KL column in Table V). The key-lock module effectively prevents GGL from inheriting the semantic and structural information of the true image. For instance, in the first row of the table, the samples generated from the GGL model without the key-lock module display a black grouse with a similar green background color and orientation as the true input image. When the key-lock module is embedded into the model, GGL can still generate images of black grouse using the same label. However, the color distribution and object orientation no longer match the true image. This is also true for the “sweatshirt” examples, where the model with the key-lock module generates four different colors of sweatshirts, none of which match the color (gray) in the true image. In terms of spatial information, significant variance can be observed across all examples when the proposed key-lock module is used. For instance, in the last column of Table V, the generated images of “pig” and “basset hound” exhibit various camera perspectives and distances of view fields. Consequently, it can be concluded that the generated images with the key-lock module are not identifiable from the true image, proving that the true image information is effectively protected from the gradient.

In order to quantitatively evaluate the proposed key-lock module against state-of-the-art gradient leakage methods, we employed four evaluation metrics, including MSE, PSNR, LPIPS (using VGGNet and AlexNet), and SSIM. In Table VI, the results were calculated from the generated images and their corresponding true images. It is consistent that the generated images from the model with the proposed key-lock module have significantly lower similarity compared to those from the model without the key-lock module. This indicates that the key-lock module can effectively defend against gradient leakage attacks. For instance, DLG with LeNet on the MNIST dataset has an MSE score of 49.9749.9749.97, while the one with the key-lock module achieves 140.87140.87140.87, which is 181.91%percent181.91181.91\% higher. When LeNet is embedded with a key-lock module, the MSE score of GRNN on the MNIST dataset increases by 29,460%29percent46029,460\%. As for PSNR, most models without the key-lock module scored between 353535 and 505050. However, when the key-lock module is integrated into the model, the PSNR scores drop to approximately 282828. In terms of LPIPS and SSIM, the former metric focuses on the semantic similarity between two images, while the latter one emphasizes structural similarity. The results from both DLG and GRNN perform significantly worse when the key-lock module is embedded into the model. Furthermore, unlike DLG and GRNN, which generate original true images from the gradient directly, the images generated by GGL are similar to the true images in terms of semantics and structure, as shown in Table V. We found that GGL with the key-lock module can still generate images with rich semantic and structural information. Nevertheless, the key-lock module can reduce the reconstruction capability of GGL by preventing the true image’s information from leaking through the gradient. As a result, the GGL without the key-lock module obtains 0.400.400.40 and 0.390.390.39 on LPIPS using VGGNet and AlexNet, respectively, whereas the results increase to 0.470.470.47 and 0.460.460.46 when the key-lock module is present. Although the SSIM score is only 0.2310.2310.231 for standard GGL, it is reduced to 0.1800.1800.180 by the key-lock module. Based on the quantitative results in Table VI, we can conclude that the proposed key-lock module is capable of effectively protecting private information from being leaked through the gradient.

4.4 Sharing Strategies of the Key-Lock Module

Our proposed module comprises two components to defend against gradient leakage in gradient-sharing-based training systems, such as FL. We theoretically demonstrated in Section 3.1 that the key-lock module can effectively prevent the inheritance of input data information from being embedded into the gradient of the model. In this section, we experimentally evaluate the influence of the key sequence and lock layer separately for gradient leakage defense. We employ three information-sharing strategies for GRNN and GGL with different backbones trained on various datasets. DLG failed to recover any true images across all scenarios, and the potential reasons have already been discussed in Section 4.3. As a result, no examples from DLG are presented in Table VII. Factors such as network complexity and image resolution are considered. The private key can be used to calculate the gradient of the lock layer, but the reverse is not possible (see Eqns. 35 & 36). Consequently, the gradient in Eqn. 37 can be inferred theoretically. When the image resolution is fixed at 32∗32323232*32, GRNN can successfully perform gradient leakage attacks by providing a private key only, while it fails to recover any meaningful visual content by providing the parameters of the key-lock module only. The image quality can be further improved by providing both the private key sequence and the parameters of the key-lock module. A similar case is observed when ResNet-18 with a resolution of 256∗256256256256*256 is used. We can conclude that although both the key and the parameters of the key-lock module contribute to gradient protection, the private key information plays a more significant role in defending against gradient leakage attacks.

5 Conclusion

In this paper, we provided comprehensive theoretical analysis on gradient leakage, based on which we proposed a gradient leakage defense method, called FedKL, for the FL system. The proposed key-lock module prevents the input data information from leaking through the gradient during the training stage. Importantly, we theoretically demonstrated the efficacy of the key-lock module in defending against gradient leakage attacks. Extensive empirical studies were conducted with three state-of-the-art attack methods. All the quantitative and qualitative comparison results indicate that by incorporating the proposed key-lock module into the model, reconstructing input images from the publicly shared gradient is no longer feasible. Additionally, we discussed the influence of the key-lock module on the model in terms of classification accuracy. The implementation of our proposed FedKL is made publicly available to ensure consistent replication and facilitate further comparison for researchers in related fields.
